question: [File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Enum: OnChainExecutionConfig] [Version migration vulnerability] Can an attacker exploit the ordering of enum variants (V1-V7 with Missing in between) to cause deserialization confusion when upgrading from older versions, potentially leading to incorrect execution config being applied? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Enum: OnChainExecutionConfig] [Backwards compatibility bypass] Does the Missing variant at line 18 create a vulnerability where attackers can force the system to revert to pre-config behavior by manipulating on-chain state, bypassing newer security features like gas limits? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: transaction_shuffler_type()] [State inconsistency] Can validators running different software versions interpret the same OnChainExecutionConfig differently due to missing exhaustive matching, causing network partition when processing transaction order? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: block_gas_limit_type()] [Gas limit bypass] In the V2/V3 conversion logic at lines 47-52, can an attacker craft a config with block_gas_limit=Some(0) to disable gas limits entirely while appearing to have limits enabled? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: transaction_deduper_type()] [Replay attack] Does the Missing variant defaulting to TxnHashAndAuthenticatorV1 at line 111 create a window where upgraded validators accept deduplicated transactions while old validators don't, allowing transaction replay? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: deserialize_into_config()] [Double deserialization exploit] Can an attacker craft malicious BCS-encoded bytes that pass the first bcs::from_bytes at line 170 but fail or produce different results on the second deserialization at line 171, causing validator disagreement? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: deserialize_into_config()] [Memory exhaustion] Does the double BCS deserialization at lines 170-171 allow an attacker to provide nested vectors that expand exponentially, causing memory exhaustion during config loading? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: deserialize_into_config()] [Type confusion] Can an attacker manipulate the raw_bytes vector to deserialize into a different OnChainExecutionConfig variant than intended, bypassing version-specific security checks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Trait: OnChainConfig] [Config injection] Are there race conditions between when the config is deserialized at line 169-173 and when it's applied, allowing an attacker to inject a malicious config during the window? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: block_gas_limit_type()] [Gas accounting bypass] Can an attacker exploit the transition from V1 (NoLimit) to V2 (with limits) to execute transactions during the upgrade window without gas restrictions, potentially causing state bloat? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: enable_per_block_gas_limit()] [Feature flag exploitation] Does the enable_per_block_gas_limit boolean at lines 60-71 create inconsistency where block_gas_limit_type returns a limit but it's not enforced if this flag is false? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Struct: ExecutionConfigV2] [Option manipulation] Can setting block_gas_limit to Some(u64::MAX) at line 184 effectively disable gas limits while maintaining the appearance of having limits, allowing DoS attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: block_gas_limit()] [Integer overflow] In BlockGasLimitType::block_gas_limit() at lines 316-325, does returning effective_block_gas_limit directly without bounds checking allow overflow when combined with multipliers? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Enum: BlockGasLimitType::ComplexLimitV1] [Gas formula manipulation] Can an attacker with governance control set execution_gas_effective_multiplier or io_gas_effective_multiplier to 0 at lines 287-288, making all execution free? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Enum: BlockGasLimitType::ComplexLimitV1] [Arithmetic overflow] Does the gas limit formula at lines 282-285 properly handle overflow when multiplying large gas values with multipliers and adding conflict penalties? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: execution_gas_effective_multiplier()] [Default bypass] Can the default value of 1 returned for NoLimit and Limit variants at lines 329-330 be exploited to undercharge for execution gas? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: io_gas_effective_multiplier()] [Gas miscalculation] Does returning 1 for non-ComplexLimitV1 variants at lines 340-341 create inconsistency in gas accounting across different config versions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Enum: BlockGasLimitType::ComplexLimitV1] [Output limit bypass] Can an attacker craft transactions that stay within effective_block_gas_limit but exceed block_output_limit by exploiting the Option<u64> at line 303, causing block propagation failures? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: block_output_limit()] [None exploitation] Does returning None for NoLimit and Limit variants at lines 351-352 allow unbounded output size, potentially causing network bandwidth exhaustion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Field: include_user_txn_size_in_block_output] [Accounting bypass] Can an attacker exploit the boolean at line 306 being false to submit large transactions that bypass block_output_limit by not including user txn size? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: include_user_txn_size_in_block_output()] [Size calculation exploit] Does the flag at lines 387-395 create inconsistency where validators with different configs calculate different block output sizes, causing chain splits? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Field: block_output_limit] [Integer limits] Can setting block_output_limit to Some(1) cause denial of service by rejecting all non-trivial blocks, halting the network? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Field: conflict_penalty_window] [DoS amplification] Can an attacker set conflict_penalty_window at line 289 to u32::MAX, causing exponential gas cost increases for any transaction with conflicts? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Function: conflict_penalty_window()] [Edge case handling] Does the check for > 1 at line 367 mean that setting the value to 1 returns None, potentially disabling conflict penalties when they should be enabled? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/on_chain_config/execution_config.rs] [Field: conflict_penalty_window] [Gas calculation manipulation] Can validators disagree on the number of conflicts within the penalty window, leading to different gas calculations and state divergence? (Critical)
